merica.name: Merica (700-1034)
merica.description: This kingdom was the domiant or second most domiant among the Anglo-Saxons from  roughly 600 to 900 AD, reaching it's peak under the reign of King Offa (reigned 757 to 796). His death saw the decline of the kingdom, as through intermarriage and conquest it became a powerful part of Wessex. The kingdom stopped being distinct, even as a vassal, around 900 AD.

wessex.name: Wessex (700-1034)
wessex.description: From the 800s to late 1000s, with the arrival of the Normons, this was the dominant kingdom. Wessex had such power, that after 900, kingdoms like Kent and Sussex were simply 'Greater Wessex'. Alfred the Great was born here and ruled over these lands.

late_kent.name: Kent (793-1034)
late_kent.description: Late Kent was a weaker, less accomplished, but proud kingdom.

anglo_danes.name: Anglo-Danes/English (1016 to 1066)
anglo_danes.description: The Danes, managed to conquer the Anglo-Saxons, and after the death of their leader and a rebellion among the various subjects, a new king rose to unite all the holdings. Even after the Danes, Norse, and other peoples were driven out a second time, the culture of the Anglo-Saxons had changed greatly. Many of their elite warriors were now 'Housecarls', much of the land was under the 'Danelaw', and the new introduced culture, like the Saxons, blended in and became an important part of the regional culture and identity.

anglian_kingdoms_heptarchy.name: Anglian Kingdoms Heptarchy (600-700 AD)
anglian_kingdoms_heptarchy.description: The Angles/Anglos had their own kingdoms that were considered part of the 'Heptarchy', specifically East Anglia, Merica, Bernicia, and Deira. The 'North Angles' (Bernica and Deira) were unified into 'Northumbria' in 604 AD, (and despite converting after almost all the Saxon Kingdoms), they then had a 'golden age of religious and artistic works' from 650-750.

northumbria.name: Northumbria (700-1066 AD)
northumbria.description: The 'North Angles' (Bernica and Deira) were unified into 'Northumbria' in 604 AD. Afterward, they were conquered by the Vikings, and then 'liberated' by the Saxons. The area was known for its heavy Norse influences and retaining its horsemen traditions, sometimes fielding entire armies that fought purely on horseback.

ealdorman.name: Ealdorman
ealdorman.description: Below the Eorls were the Ealdormen, who were the appointed rulers of 'shires' and/or members of previously defeated royal families. As such, not every Ealdorman was equal, with the previous leaders of kingdoms having remained part of their power, just with a new King ruling over them. This position was political and not a social rank.

earl.name: Eorl
earl.description: Below the rank of 'king', there was the rank of 'eorl' (Later Earl, which was a had a common shared ancestor with the word 'Jarl), which signified a powerful leader with much land and power (Such as a duke). Such powerful noble leaders often lead armies in the place of the King himself.

aetheling.name: Aetheling
aetheling.description: The word 'Aetheling' was desended from Saxon, Germanic, and Anglos words, and meant 'belonging to, a royal family'. This term was often used for princes and people of the royal family, who were not the king or queen.

cyning.name: Cyning
cyning.description: The term 'Cyning', is a sibling word of 'king' and as such has the same meaning. As such, the 'Cyning' ruled over a 'Cyningdom', of which there was many before any specific Cyningdom was able to conquer the others.

cwene.name: Cwene
cwene.description: Cwene, pronounced (kwĕnə), is a sibling word of 'Queen' from Old English, and as such has the same meaning.

abbod.name: Abbod/Abbot
abbod.description: As the Anglos and Saxons christianized, The Church became a center of their lives. As the wealthy churches across the land were frequent targets of raids, the local religious leader could end up having to help organize a defense.

north_abbod.name: Abbod/Abbot
north_abbod.description: As the Anglos and Saxons christianized, The Church became a center of their lives. As the wealthy churches across the land were frequent targets of raids, the local religious leader could end up having to help organize a defense.

priest.name: Christian Priest
priest.description: For the lives of rural living people, religion has always been at the center. During these dark and desperate times, for many in Europe, the Christian faith was the only hope they had.

low_bordweall.name: Ceorl Bordweall
low_bordweall.description: A band of freemen/ceorls (Pronouced Churls), who in exchange for their lands and their freedom, serve their lord in martial service 2 months a year. As is the tradition of these people, they fight shoulder to shoulder, in the 'shield wall'. A Ceorl, being free, was not property and neither was his children. The Ceorl often owned his own lands, but paid taxes in return for protection.

great_bordweall.name: Thegn Bordweall
great_bordweall.description: Minor noblemen (Thegn), 'wealthy peasants' (Geneats), and what appears to be some of the middle class, made up a class of 'retainers' who served the king and his nobles. They were the more experienced, martial foundation of Anglo-Saxon Armies. The poorest thegn had enough land to support five whole families.

merican_thegn.name: Merican/Kent Thegn Bordweall
merican_thegn.description: Minor noblemen (Thegn), 'wealthy peasants' (Geneats), and what appears to be some of the middle class, made up a class of 'retainers' who served the king and his nobles. They were the more experienced, martial foundation of Anglo-Saxon Armies. The poorest thegn had enough land to support five whole families.

northumbria_thegn.name: Northumbria Thegn Bordweall
northumbria_thegn.description: Minor noblemen (Thegn), 'wealthy peasants' (Geneats), and what appears to be some of the middle class, made up a class of 'retainers' who served the king and his nobles. They were the more experienced, martial foundation of Anglo-Saxon Armies. The poorest thegn had enough land to support five whole families.

northumbria_thegn_cav.name: Northumbria Thegn Horsemen
northumbria_thegn_cav.description: Minor noblemen (Thegn), 'wealthy peasants' (Geneats), and what appears to be some of the middle class, made up a class of 'retainers' who served the king and his nobles. They were the more experienced, martial foundation of Anglo-Saxon Armies. The poorest thegn had enough land to support five whole families.

geburs.name: Geburs
geburs.description: Like many cultures, including the Romans, those who couldn't fully afford their own spear and shield often fought as skirmishers. Geburs were indeed 'freemen' and thus 'Ceorls', but they didn't independently own enough land to support their families. As such they had to work 2 days out of the week, at least, on their lord's lands. Many of them were former slaves, or the desendents of such people.

geburs_spear.name: Gebur Spearmen
geburs_spear.description: Like many cultures, including the Romans, those who couldn't fully afford their own spear and shield often fought as skirmishers. Geburs were indeed 'freemen' and thus 'Ceorls', but they didn't independently own enough land to support their families. As such they had to work 2 days out of the week, at least, on their lord's lands. Many of them were former slaves, or the desendents of such people.

huscarl.name: Huscarls
huscarl.description: A 'housecarl' (Old Norse húskarl, Old English huscarl, translates to 'house man'), was a type of 'retainer' and loyal fighting man, much like many of the minor nobility. What made the Huscarl special, was how it was a mixture of the cultural tradition of the Saxon gedribt 'hearthguard' and the Norse 'hindmen'.

Duguth_Bordweall.name: Duguth Spearmen Bordweall
Duguth_Bordweall.description: The Dugutb (pronounced Doo-gutb) were the more experienced and accomplished warriors, and like many other cultures, including other 'barbarians' and even the Romans, older men typically had better equipment, resilience, and experience. As Saxon warlords or nobles gained power and grew older, they would draw in more and more of these experienced fighters, along with having their inexperienced fighters become experienced over time.

Duguth_Light.name: Light Duguth Warriors
Duguth_Light.description: The Dugutb (pronounced Doo-gutb) were the more experienced and accomplished warriors, and like many other cultures, including other 'barbarians' and even the Romans, older men typically had better equipment, resilience, and experience. As Saxon warlords or nobles gained power and grew older, they would draw in more and more of these experienced fighters, along with having their inexperienced fighters become experienced over time.

light_geoguth.name: Light Geoguth Warriors
light_geoguth.description: A band of Geoguth (Pronouced Yoo-Guths), was the young men and boys of a warband. Typically these men followed less experienced leaders, warlords, and chieftains

heavy_geoguth.name: Geoguth Spearmen Warriors
heavy_geoguth.description: A band of Geoguth (Pronouced Yoo-Guths), was the young men and boys of a warband. Typically these men followed less experienced leaders, warlords, and chieftains.

ceorl.name: Ceorl Militia
ceorl.description: A band of freemen/ceorls (Pronouced Churls), typically made up of the conquered peoples living within the lands of a Saxon/Angles king, warlord, or noble. A Ceorl, being free, was not property and neither was his children. The Ceorl often owned his own lands, but paid taxes in return for protection.

heavy_hearthguard.name: Heavy Hearthguard
heavy_hearthguard.description: The Gedribt/Gedriht (pronounced Tedrict/Yedrict) were like the 'Angle' lord's 'hearthguard'. These men were known to have unflinchy loyalty and were willing to do any act of cruelity or violence without thought for their 'lord'. In exchange, they are given honor, glory, respect, all the finer things in life, women, and a place by the fire. These wealthier of these men even owned and rode horses into battle.

companions.name: Lord's Companions
companions.description: After the Angles, Britians, and Saxons merged into a single culture, it is not clear what the warrior elite serving the local 'count', 'king', 'aetheling',or 'ealdorman', were known as. Some sources call these men 'Companions', 'Hearthguard', or 'Royal Bodyguard', but these terms are clearly not from the time period. These men were known to have unflinchy loyalty and were willing to do any act of cruelity or violence without thought for their 'lord'. In exchange, they are given honor, glory, respect, all the finer things in life, women, and a place by the fire. These wealthier of these men even owned and rode horses into battle.

brythonic_skirmishers.name: Brythonic Skirmishers
brythonic_skirmishers.description: 'Brythonic' refers to people who spoke a 'celtic language', mainly the 'Britons' who lived in Brittany, the Welish, and the Britons who once ruled the lands that would become England. Like many cultures, including the Romans, those who couldn't fully afford their own spear and shield often fought as skirmishers.

emperor_brythonic_skirmishers.name: Athelstan's Brythonic Skirmishers
emperor_brythonic_skirmishers.description: 'Brythonic' refers to people who spoke a 'celtic language', mainly the 'Britons' who lived in Brittany, the Welish, and the Britons who once ruled the lands that would become England. Like many cultures, including the Romans, those who couldn't fully afford their own spear and shield often fought as skirmishers.

strathclyde.name: Strathclyde Warriors
strathclyde.description: Between what became England and Scotland, were lands populated by a 'Brythonic' people, who were ethnically very similar to the Welish. Among the 'Britons', they were remarkable for their abiltiy on horseback.

early_strathclyde.name: Early Strathclyde Warriors
early_strathclyde.description: Between what became England and Scotland, were lands populated by a 'Brythonic' people, who were ethnically very similar to the Welish. Among the 'Britons', they were remarkable for their abiltiy on horseback.

strathclyde_north.name: Strathclyde Warriors
strathclyde_north.description: Between what became England and Scotland, were lands populated by a 'Brythonic' people, who were ethnically very similar to the Welish. Among the 'Britons', they were remarkable for their abiltiy on horseback. There is some evidence that the Northumbrians might've ruled over some of them, but much more evidence of their use as mercenaries or allies against the invading Norse.There is some evidence that the Northumbrians might've ruled over some of them, but much more evidence of their use as mercenaries or allies against the invading Norse.

modest_bordweall.name: Geneat Bordweall
modest_bordweall.description: Minor noblemen (Thegn), 'wealthy peasants' (Geneats), and what appears to be some of the middle class, made up a class of 'retainers' who served the king and his nobles. They were the more experienced, martial foundation of Anglo-Saxon Armies. A ceorl (freeman) who ended up with enough land to become 'peasant aristocracy' or 'middle class', was a Geneat (They're still a ceorl, and not nobility). Geneats were odd, in that sometimes they were freemen saving up to have enough land to be Thegns (Who are actual minor nobility), and other times they were even richer, but uninterested in being professional soldiers.

visionary.name: Visionary
visionary.description:
When this unit is activated, choose up to X friendly _Infantry_ units within 6" to receive one of the following bonuses until the end of the round: 
 * Re-roll failed Accuracy tests of 9+ 
 * Re-roll failed Strength tests of 9+ 
 * Re-roll failed Reflex tests of 9+ 
 * +3'' Movement.

high_administrator.name: High Administrator
high_administrator.description:
When this unit is activated, choose up to 2 friendly _Infantry_ units within 6" to receive TWO of the following bonuses until the end of the round: 
 * Re-roll failed Accuracy tests of 9+ 
 * Re-roll failed Strength tests of 9+ 
 * Re-roll failed Reflex tests of 9+ 
 * +3'' Movement.

looking_for_the_emperor.name: Looking For the Emperor
looking_for_the_emperor.description: This unit can only be recruited if the relic 'Athelstan' has been selected

men_of_the_north.name: Men of the North
men_of_the_north.description: This unit can only be recruited if the relic 'Edwin' has been selected

aethelbert.name: Aethelbert
aethelbert.flavor: Aethelbert was the first Anglo or Saxon king to convert to Christianity and one of the first of such kings to have quality coinage minted. Until Offa, Kent had the best coinage in the British Isles, superior to even France perhaps.

offa.name: Offa
offa.flavor: Almost a hundred years before Alfred the Great, a previous king of the Mercians tried to unite the Anglo-Saxons. However, according to some historians; 'Offa was driven by a lust for power, not a vision of English unity'. The domiance of his kingdom and family line was not to last.
offa.description: Any unit of 'Merican Thegn Bordweall' can obtain the 'light infantry' rule.

edwin.name: Edwin of Northumbria
edwin.flavor: Edwin was the second king of Northumbria, and its first Christian king. His 'imperium' took many cultural cues from the Romans, and his power matched that of the later Saxon Bretwaldas (Britain-ruler).

alfred.name: Alfred the Great
alfred.flavor: Alfred the Great is believed by many to be the man who made 'England' a reality, by becoming King of all the Anglo-Saxons. Through his wisdom, character, and massive construction of fortified settlements and 'castles', he defeated the Danish Vikings.
alfred.description: Upgrade one Cyning model by replacing 'Field Orders' with 'Visionary'

athelstan.name: Athelstan, First King of England
athelstan.flavor: Athelstan was the grandson of Alfred the Great, and the first King to unite the various Anglo-Saxons kingdoms into what became England. His domain was so wide, he was known as 'Emperor of Britian'.
athelstan.description: 'Brythonic Skirmishers' are counted as 'common' instead of 'rare' and all caps on their numbers are lifted

harold.name: King Harold, last Anglo-Saxon King of England
harold.flavor: History is not certain if Harold was the rightful king or England or a manipulative bastard, but he tried really hard to keep the Vikings and Normans from taking his throne.
harold.description: Upgrade one Cyning model. When this leader is deployed, this unit and up to 2 units within 6' get 'Scout'

Æthelflæd.name: Æthelflæd, Lady of the Mercians
Æthelflæd.flavor: Æthelflæd was the daughter of Alfred the Great. While not exactly a great warrior or commander, she is given credit for a lot of the achievements made during the period. It is likely her husband and father would've accomplished suitably less, without her help.
Æthelflæd.description: Upgrade one Cwene model with 'High Administrator'.

strategies.name: Shield Wall
strategies.description: Only units with shields and spears equipped (light infantry not included), if that unit moved one or no times this round, and if charged or targeted by a shooting attack it gets +1 Save (But only against one attack) and ignores the 'superior_cavalry' rule. This effect remains in place till the unit moves.
strategies.flavor: The bordweall (Old English for 'Shield Wall'), was a tactic and model of fighting that grew popular with the Anglo-Saxons right before or around the start of the Viking Invasion. Communities were organized into sizes that would produce a 'fyrd', which is a part time militia of freemen/ceorls, who fought shoulder to shoulder in formation.

strategies.name: Veterans
strategies.description: Use when a Thegn unit attacks. You may re-roll all dice and they may not be re-rolled again. A unit may only be affected by this strategy once.
strategies.flavor: Many years of campaigning have given Wessex or the Anglian kingdoms a pool of hardened veterans.

strategies.name: Combined Units
strategies.description: A _Thegn_ unit can join a _Ceorl_ unit before the game for 1 point each. Only one _Thegn_ unit can be attached to a _Ceorl_ unit.

strategies.name: Follow The Example
strategies.description: 'Use when activating a 'Low-Combined' unit which is combined with a Thegn unit. It gains +1 Strength until the end of the turn.

strategies.name: Bolster
strategies.description: Use when an Infantry unit is targeted by an enemy. If it did not move this round, that unit may increase its cover level by 1 (none to normal, normal to fortified).

strategies.name: Wall With Spikes
strategies.description: Choose 1 or 2 units with the 'spearman' rule, which are being charged. Increase their Initiative by +1 during any attempt to 'Counter Attack'.
